Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to check for recommended latest automatically?" (#6193) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Is there a programmatic way to check for the latest recommended version?

https://www.nuget.org/downloads shows 4.7.0 as recommended latest but the underlying source view for the page doesn't have the string 4.7.0 in it and the url is just https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest/nuget.exe

In trying to keep the Homebrew nuget formula up to date, currently I have to manually visit https://www.nuget.org/downloads from time to time to see if there is an update, but I'd like to automate that checking so that `brew livecheck nuget` actually works.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Upload page shouldn't show an in-progress upload if the in-progress package is already available" (#6192) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
In addition to the update at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/6176

The upload page shouldn't show an upload as in-progress if the package that is being reference is already available.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Management of accounts with non default security policies appears broken" (#6191) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "[NuGet Symbol Server] Add core symbol package service" (#6190) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Adds the entity and definitions required by gallery, jobs and orchestrator. Also added tests.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "V3:  Feed2Catalog:  time zone bug" (#6189) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Although feed datetime values lack an explicit time zone indicator (e.g.:  "Z"), [they represent UTC](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/blob/522605c7986c98244a196472c50f20f2f2de0ccc/src/Catalog/Helpers/FeedHelpers.cs#L206).

`FeedHelpers.ForceUtc(...)` [attempts to convert a `DateTime` to UTC](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/blob/522605c7986c98244a196472c50f20f2f2de0ccc/src/Catalog/Helpers/FeedHelpers.cs#L228), but it does not handle the default case on a dev machine where `DateTime.Kind` is `DateTimeKind.Local`.

This results in tests failing on a dev machine (or any machine where time is not in UTC) but passing on a CI machine.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "V3:  Feed2Catalog:  time zone bug" (#6189) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Although feed datetime values lack an explicit time zone indicator (e.g.:  "Z"), [they represent UTC](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/blob/522605c7986c98244a196472c50f20f2f2de0ccc/src/Catalog/Helpers/FeedHelpers.cs#L206).

`FeedHelpers.ForceUtc(...)` [attempts to convert a `DateTime` to UTC](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/blob/522605c7986c98244a196472c50f20f2f2de0ccc/src/Catalog/Helpers/FeedHelpers.cs#L228), but it does not handle the default case on a dev machine where `DateTime.Kind` is `DateTimeKind.Local`.

This results in tests failing on a dev machine (or any machine where time is not in UTC) but passing on a CI machine.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Revalidation] Add Admin Panel" (#6172) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This change adds two features:

* A revalidation state service - This service allows parallel updates to the state. This is used by the Gallery, and later, the revalidation job for things like the killswitch and the desired revalidation rate.
* An admin UI to stop/start the revalidation job.

# Screenshots

## Default view

![activate](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/42833049-f5d43008-89a7-11e8-97bd-6aa24b761a14.png)

# View if Revalidation job is killswitched

![enable-revalidations](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/42833063-fce71f0e-89a7-11e8-9cf0-05e2e906af7e.png)

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1437

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Large package size should be rejected with 413 - Payload too large" (#6143) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: I believe IIS rejects with 500 right now.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow packages that failed signing validation to be re-submitted by the customer" (#5345) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, when a package fails validation the user must publish a new version of the package to fix the issue. For example, suppose they use an untrusted timestamping server for signing. This can be fixed pretty easily by the customer so it makes sense to allow them to republish that same package version after they resign the package.

This needs some design, but it general it makes sense I think.

/cc @karann-msft

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add NuGet.exe to the Developer Command Prompt" (#7133) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Please make NuGet.exe available from the Visual Studio Developer Command Prompt. It's a commonly needed tool and the expectation is that `msbuild`, `dotnet` and `nuget` just work from the command prompt.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageDependencyResolution: JoinItems task failed: Path too long" (#7132) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
MSBuild: 15.8.160-preview+gaf9d27ba72
15.8.160.40367
VS Version: 15.8.0 Preview 5.0 [27917.1.d15.8]

Repro project:
\\mlangfs1\public\kirillo\NuGetJoinItemsPathTooLong\ddafsdsadfs.zip

Build using MSBuild (zip contains .binlog). You get error:
```
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.400-preview-009088\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(421,5): error MSB4018: The "JoinItems" task failed unexpectedly.
System.InvalidOperationException: The item metadata "%(FileName)" cannot be applied to the path "C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.400-preview-009088\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\..\..\..\..\NuGetFallbackFolder\microsoft.aspnetcore.server.kestrel.transport.abstractions\2.0.0\lib\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Transport.Abstractions.dll". The specified path, file name, or both are too long. The fully qualified file name must be less than 260 characters, and the directory name must be less than 248 characters.
   at Microsoft.Build.Shared.ErrorUtilities.ThrowInvalidOperation(String resourceName, Object[] args)
   at Microsoft.Build.Shared.FileUtilities.ItemSpecModifiers.GetItemSpecModifier(String currentDirectory, String itemSpec, String definingProjectEscaped, String modifier, String& fullPath)
   at Microsoft.Build.Evaluation.BuiltInMetadata.GetMetadataValueEscaped(String currentDirectory, String evaluatedIncludeBeforeWildcardExpansionEscaped, String evaluatedIncludeEscaped, String definingProjectEscaped, String name, String& fullPath)
   at Microsoft.Build.Execution.ProjectItemInstance.TaskItem.GetBuiltInMetadataEscaped(String name)
   at Microsoft.Build.Execution.ProjectItemInstance.TaskItem.GetMetadataEscaped(String metadataName)
   at Microsoft.Build.Execution.ProjectItemInstance.TaskItem.GetMetadata(String metadataName)
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.JoinItems.<>c__DisplayClass32_0.<ExecuteCore>b__0(ITaskItem item)
   at System.Linq.Enumerable.<JoinIterator>d__38`4.MoveNext()
   at System.Linq.Buffer`1..ctor(IEnumerable`1 source)
   at System.Linq.Enumerable.ToArray[TSource](IEnumerable`1 source)
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.JoinItems.ExecuteCore()
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.TaskBase.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskExecutionHost.Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.ITaskExecutionHost.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskBuilder.<ExecuteInstantiatedTask>d__26.MoveNext() [C:\Users\toddgrun\Documents\Projects\ddafsdsadfs\ddafsdsadfs\ddafsdsadfs.csproj]
```

This is because the paths in question (Item `ResolvedCompileFileDefinitions`) are too long (261 characters). They are an output of the `ResolvePackageAssets` task. 

Our understanding is that the long paths are coming from the project.assets.json file (included in the .zip). In fact here's what we see there:

```
  "packageFolders": {
    "C:\\Users\\kirill\\.nuget\\packages\\": {},
    "C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\sdk\\2.1.400-preview-009088\\Sdks\\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\\targets\\..\\..\\..\\..\\NuGetFallbackFolder": {}
  },
```

We think that the path that contains `..\..\..\` should be shortened using Path.GetFullPath() at some point, but we don't know where's the best place to make this change.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stop always forcing problem with nuget.exe" (#7131) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
What is always stupid exception?

Error NU5012: Unable to find '**.dll'. Make sure the project has been built.

I already built Release dll and it doesn't see my library. I feel mad because nuget steals my time much.
Please stop forcing my time!

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<package  xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2013/05/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3</id>
    <version>0.1</version>
    <title>MonoGame Framework Control for Gtk Sharp 3</title>
    <authors>Jens Eckervogt</authors>
    <owners>Jens Eckervogt</owners>
    <licenseUrl>https://github.com/sourceskyboxer/MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3</licenseUrl>
    <projectUrl>https://github.com/sourceskyboxer/MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3</projectUrl>
    <iconUrl>https://i.imgur.com/nC1iu3N.png</iconUrl>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <description>MonoGame's Editor Environment for Gtk Sharp 3.22x.</description>
    <releaseNotes>Initial release!</releaseNotes>
    <copyright>2018, SourceSkyBoxer from Germany</copyright>
    <tags>MonoGame, Gtk-Sharp</tags>
    <dependencies>
      <dependency id="gtk-sharp-3" version="[3.22.6.4]" />
    </dependencies>
    <summary></summary>
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="bin\Release\MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3.dll" target="lib" />
  </files>
</package>
```

And I want type my command:
1. nuget.exe config -Set repositoryPath=C:\Users\SSB\Downloads\MonoGame.Framework.Gtk-m`aster\MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3-master\MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3`
2. `nuget.exe pack -IncludeReferencedProjects -properties Configuration=Release MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3.csproj`
3. Throws error: Error `NU5012: Unable to find 'MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3.dll'. Make sure the project has been built`

But hello I already built in release version:
here my sources
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3496136/42970811-a21cbd72-8baa-11e8-9c29-366ac97b02f5.png)

next bin directory
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3496136/42970828-b26ff32e-8baa-11e8-9325-ec220b29048a.png)

3. Release directory here it is proof "MonoGame.Framework.Gtk3.dll"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3496136/42970877-d8bc8542-8baa-11e8-8f0f-b1441fb016ae.png)

Why is nuget always lying to me if I have already built existing dlls?

I already downloaded latest version of nuget.exe

It seems like faking and lying me! Grr I feel mad because nuget steals time.

Please tell me! I am new for nuget I already read [step to step](https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/1214420/Creating-a-Nuget-Package-Step-by-Step). but for me doesn't work

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "please automatically update dependencies in .nuspec file when update package reference by Nuget Manager" (#7123) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@softboy99 commented on [Fri Jul 13 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6164)

please automatically update dependencies in .nuspec file when update package reference by Nuget Manager,Otherwise, when forget to update the dependencies in .nuspec file manually, after package builded and published, it will cause the MSBuild runtime error for loading the old version dependency when this package being used.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Is periodically deleting the `project.assets.json` (the whole obj folder) going to cause problems for nuget?" (#7120) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Per [this comment](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7098#issuecomment-404984941)
> ...there is the concept of the project.assets.json file (it is under the obj/ directory). This file has all the information about the dependencies (top level and transitive) references in a given project and where they are stored.


In order to get a _clean_ build with as little reference "help" from VS as possible, it is required that I delete the bin/obj folders prior to building the solution/project. Is periodically deleting this `project.assets.json` going to be a problem?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure][Signing] No error show when install signed package with untrusted signing certificate" (#6318) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version : Dev-4721

VS version : D15.6 27213.01 

OS version : RS3_Release 16299.15.170928-1534

## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a new test certificate:  .\CreateTestCertificate.ps1 –AddAsTrustedRootAuthority.
2. Sign a package:  NuGet.exe sign <PackageFilePath> -CertificatePath <PfxFilePath>.
3. Launch Microsoft Management Console (mmc.exe).
4. In Microsoft Management Console, navigate on the main menu to File | "Add/Remove Snap-in..."
5. In the subsequent "Add or Remove Snap-ins" dialog, select Certificates in the left-hand list.
6. Click the Add button.
7. In the subsequent "Certificates snap-in" dialog, select "My user account."
8. Click the Finish button.
9. Click the OK button.
10. In the left-hand tree pane, navigate to "Console Root" | "Certificates - Current User" | "Trusted Root Certification Authorities" | Certificates.
11. In the right-hand list pane, find the certificate that was created in step 1.  The certificate "Issued To" will be "Test certificate for testing NuGet package signing".
12. Right-click on the certificate and select “Delete”.
13. In Package Manager UI, install the package into a project.
14. Verify the previous step failed with an error saying "Certificate chain validation failed with error: UntrustedRoot."
15. Verify the package was not installed in the project.

## Expected:
There is an error saying "Certificate chain validation failed with error: UntrustedRoot" and the package was not installed in the project.

### Actual:
There is no error show and the package is installed in the project successfully as below screenshot.
![1215](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632775/34024936-e9f72a74-e187-11e7-865f-88bc3ad857ac.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageResolver.Resolve throws ArgumentOutOfRangeException for empty list of targets" (#7130) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Given empty list of targets, [PackageResolver.Resolve](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Resolver/PackageResolver.cs#L26) in the assembly NuGet.Resolver in package [NuGet.Resolver](https://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.Resolver/4.7.0) throws ArgumentOutOfRangeException.

To reproduce:

    using NuGet.Common;
    using NuGet.Configuration;
    using NuGet.Packaging;
    using NuGet.Packaging.Core;
    using NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types;
    using NuGet.Resolver;

    new PackageResolver().Resolve(new PackageResolverContext(DependencyBehavior.Highest, Array.Empty<string>(), Array.Empty<string>(), Array.Empty<PackageReference>(), Array.Empty<PackageIdentity>(), Array.Empty<SourcePackageDependencyInfo>(), Array.Empty<PackageSource>(), NullLogger.Instance), CancellationToken.None);

Expected: PackageResolver.Resolve returns empty set of packages. This is the minimal solution.

What actually happens: 

    System.ArgumentOutOfRangeException
    HResult=0x80131502
    Message=Index was out of range. Must be non-negative and less than the size of the collection.
    Parameter name: index
    Source=mscorlib
    StackTrace:
    at System.ThrowHelper.ThrowArgumentOutOfRangeException(ExceptionArgument argument, ExceptionResource resource)
    at NuGet.Resolver.CombinationSolver`1.<GetSortedList>d__18.MoveNext()
    at NuGet.Resolver.CombinationSolver`1.MoveForward(Int32 i, Boolean& consistent)
    at NuGet.Resolver.CombinationSolver`1.FindSolution(Action`1 diagnosticOutput)
    at NuGet.Resolver.CombinationSolver`1.FindSolution(IEnumerable`1 groupedItems, IComparer`1 itemSorter, Func`3 shouldRejectPairFunc, Action`1 diagnosticOutput)
    at NuGet.Resolver.PackageResolver.Resolve(PackageResolverContext context, CancellationToken token)

I am filing bug here following https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client#feedback

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Test Failure] Full restore instead of 'No-op restore' occur for the first MSBuild restore" (#7129) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Release-4.8.0-RTM 4.8.0.5348
VS Version: D15.8 27918.00
OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Create a C# Console App (.NET Core 2.1) project. 
2. Wait for the project auto restore completely. 
3. Go to the VS developer command prompt and do ‘msbuild /t:restore /v:d’. 

## Expected
No-Op restore will show at the end of the log.
## Actual
Full restore instead of ‘No-op restore’ show at the end of the log as below screenshot. No-Op restore will be shown for the **second** executing of ‘msbuild /t:restore /v:d’.
![fullrestore](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/42936848-d22cfa9a-8b3c-11e8-966f-c700da92cce9.PNG)

## Note
1. It doesn’t repro on the PMC.
2. It doesn’t repro on D16.0stg 27916.3001 + NuGet Client Dev 5.0.0.5346.
3. It repro on other .NET Core template, .NET Framework project and ASP.NET .NET Core project.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "You might still have a problem with VS" (#7127) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@Rod-in-NM commented on [Tue Jul 17 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/983)

I have been struggling with this issue. I wasn't able to check in the project into TFVC. I talked with our TFS admin. He said that even though I had manually deleted the packages folder, VS 2017 still thought that the packages folder existed, at least as a part of the solution. I had to Undo packages and all of the files under it, before VS would let me check it in.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure] ‘Tool No-Op Restore’ doesn’t work for ASP .NET Core Web Application (.NET Core 2.1)" (#7077) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev 4.8.0.5314
VS Version: D15.8stg 27828.3003
OS Version: Windows 10 RS4_Release 17134.1.180410-1804

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
1.	Create an ASP .NET Core Web Application (.NET Core 2.1).
2.	Set the diagnostics build format through Tools->Options->Projects and Solutions->Build and Run.
3.	Build the project.

## Expected
The build restore should be no-op for both the tool and the project restore.

## Actual
The build restore is no-op for just the project restore (the ‘Tool No-Op Restore’ doesn’t work) as below screenshot.
![toolnoopdoesnotwork](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/42085119-0e86253e-7b7f-11e8-9cd7-319d750f69ed.png)

## Note:
1.	It doesn’t repro for ASP .NET Core Web Application (.NET Core 2.0) on the same machine.
2.	It repro for ‘msbuild /t:restore /v:d’.
3.	It repro on D15.8stg 27828.3003 (default NuGet Client 4.8.0.5278).
4.	Repro Machine: 172.16.194.30 (Added Nikolche's alias into the administrators group).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show outdated packages " (#27) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet `outdated` command spec to show outdated packages, is ready for **review**:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org accepts signed packages" (#26) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: Starting today May, 22nd 2018.  NuGet.org accepts signed packages. More information in the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180522/Introducing-signed-package-submissions.html)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint
